title: Rugby League World Nines 2019 Live: Day one, Bankwest Stadium, updates, news, scores, highlights, video
text:
Departing NRL star Gareth Widdop has declared St George Illawarra's season a "disaster" as the star prepares for his final rugby league act on Australian soil.

After a decade in Australia, starting with the Melbourne Storm before heading to the Dragons in 2014, Widdop is set to head back to England to join Warrington on a three-year deal.

The 30-year-old will have to rely on an international game in Australia, World Club Challenge or a late career NRL lifeline to play again at the top level in Australia.

While he admits his wife and kids are all Australian, he said he could return one day.

But the star had a horror final season, dislocating his shoulder in round three, returning only when the Dragons were all but out of finals contention.

Speaking to NRL.com, Widdop said he hoped he'd left the Dragons in the better place than they were in when he started.

"The club's come a long way since then. Certainly the last few years we improved a hell of a lot," he said.

"We planned to win trophies and we haven't managed to do that but I'd certainly like to think I've contributed a little bit in improving the club.

"Obviously this year was a disaster, I guess. Injuries, off-field [incidents] – all sorts of little things that you can never write in a fairytale ending. Sometimes that's just life, it throws curve balls.

"It was very hard to take and disappointing to finish on that note but I'd like to think I've given my everything for the last six years."

Widdop will represent England in the World Nines, although it will be a first, having not played in the NRL Nines for the Dragons.
